CoverPara.Text: Explanatory notes to the Bill, prepared by the [Name to be replaced], are published separately as ...
[Name to be replaced] has made the following statement under section 19(1)(a) of the Human Rights Act 1998:
In my view the provisions of the Scottish Referendum (Consultation) Bill [HL] are compatible with the Convention rights.

Para.Text: Make provision for certain Scottish people resident outside Scotland to be consulted ahead of the 2014 referendum on Scottish independence.

Be it enacted by the Queen’s most Excellent Majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the Lords Spiritual and Temporal, and Commons, in this present Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, as follows:—

P2para.Text: The Secretary of State shall make arrangements for the consultation of certain Scottish people who are resident outside Scotland before the referendum on Scottish independence takes place on 18 September 2014.
The results of the consultation shall be made available to the public at least one month prior to the date of the referendum.

The questions to be asked in the consultation exercise under subsection (1) shall be specified by the Secretary of State and shall be designed to elicit information from eligible persons about their views on the prospect of Scottish independence and on the forthcoming referendum.
For the purposes of this Act, a person shall be eligible to be consulted under subsection (1) if they are aged 16 or over on the date of the consultation and—

P3para.Text: they were born in Scotland but now reside elsewhere in the United Kingdom or the Commonwealth, or
their domicile of origin is Scotland but they reside elsewhere in the United Kingdom or the Commonwealth.

P2para.Text: This Act may be cited as the Scottish Referendum (Consultation) Act 2014.
This Act comes into force on the day on which it is passed.
